posts.name: Alfa
posts.cooked: Hi, Our team is out to buy a swerve drive for next season. We’re upgrading to the PDH and will be going to buy MK4i’s with Kraken X60’s, I was wondering how many and what rating breakers should I buy… thanks
Since swerve uses 8 motors, you need at minimum 8 40A breakers. It’s a good idea to buy spares too. Good luck!

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked: 30a breakers also work fine for steer motors.
still generally good to use uniformly 40a for drivebase motors

posts.name: Eric Bergquist
posts.cooked: Do you have a technical reason for that statement?

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked: I agree with that statement unless you are using the CTRE PDP like we are. if you give all the drivebase motors 40A slots on a PDP , you are left with no high amperage slots for subsystems. even then, a steer motor wont draw more than 30A.
uniformity? standardizing with 40a breakers makes life a lot easier

posts.name: Zach
posts.cooked:
Our team uses 30A breakers for the Steer motors mainly just out of habit. As @Henry_B stated, it saved space for other subsystems on the PDP high-current rail, and just carried over to the PDH . The color coded breakers also helps us know which slot is the steer vs drive motor before even reading labels.

The motors definitely will draw over 30A, just not long enough to trip the breaker. The code has the current limit set to around 60A with drive set to 90A (on a 40A breaker).

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked:
I don’t really agree. I like running 30A (or even 20A) on steering motors, as it makes it makes it easier to know what’s what when looking at the PDH at a glance. We’ve never had a steering breaker trip except for an instance where the module mechanically failed and couldn’t spin (having a lower breaker there kept the motor cooler too…). Using 30A also opens the steering motors up to using 14 AWG wire, which can again help you distinguish what’s what if you ran out of time and didn’t label things.

There’s no performance benefit to running 40A breakers on steering motors. All you get out of it is having less to think about while wiring your robot. If that’s what you want, it’s fine, but there’s nothing wrong with doing something different.

thats understandable, i have never really thought about its usefulness in that regard. we primarily use drivebase type motors across the whole robot, so we generally just stock a bunch of 40a breakers in our pit.

posts.name: Jake Potter
posts.cooked: I learned from other LRIs this year that the PDP ’s small slots can be used with 12 gauge wire and 40 amp breakers.  Apparently FIRST validated it with CTRE … Although where that’s documented, I don’t know.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.custom_user_title: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked: We use 12ga stranded with ferrules in the small slots of the PDP .  The Rev PDH breakers will fit in the PDP ’s low amperage slots meaning that you could put a 40a breaker in but it’s against the game rules I believe.

posts.name: Adam Fleming
posts.cooked: I’m 99.9% certain the rules do allow for the Rev 40a breakers to be used in the CTRE PDP . I can’t find it, but I remember someone asking about it in the Q&A a  previous season and it was allowed.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FRC 3596 Lead Mentor/Alum, FTC 30607 Lead Mentor

posts.name: Henry Becker
posts.cooked: I went back and checked, I must have missed that in my previous research. The game rules allow it, however, CTRE states in their PDP manual that they are only rated to 30A.
